name: D. Bacterial Melee
statement:
Julia is conducting an experiment in her lab. She placed several
luminescent bacterial colonies in a horizontal testtube. Different types
of bacteria can be distinguished by the color of light they emit. Julia
marks types of bacteria with small Latin letters "", ..., "".The
testtube is divided into consecutive regions. Each region is occupied by
a single colony of a certain bacteria type at any given moment. Hence,
the population of the testtube at any moment can be described by a
string of Latin characters.Sometimes a colony can decide to conquer
another colony in one of the adjacent regions. When that happens, the
attacked colony is immediately eliminated and replaced by a colony of
the same type as the attacking colony, while the attacking colony keeps
its type. Note that a colony can only attack its neighbours within the
boundaries of the testtube. At any moment, at most one attack can take
place.For example, consider a testtube with population "". There are six
options for an attack that may happen next: the first colony attacks the
second colony (), the resulting population is ""; , the result is ""; ,
the result is ""; , the result is "" (note that the result is the same
as the first option); or , the population does not change.The pattern of
attacks is rather unpredictable. Julia is now wondering how many
different configurations of bacteria in the testtube she can obtain
after a sequence of attacks takes place (it is possible that no attacks
will happen at all). Since this number can be large, find it modulo .
